Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I completed for you, oh sons, this book, which is the last of the science of medicine with its complement, and I reached the end in it, from its explanations and declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of the operation, that is, surgery by hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since the operation by hand has been neglected in our region and time, and has been completely abandoned; until perhaps its science has perished and its track has been cut off; and there have not remained of it except small descriptions in the books of the ancients, which hands have altered; and error and hesitation occurred to them, until its intentions were closed and its use was prolonged: It seemed to me that I should revive it with the organization of this Treatise in it, according to the method of exposition, declaration, and abbreviation; and that I should come with the forms of iron instruments of cauterization, and other instruments of work; with the addition of declarations, and with the preparation of what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason for which a good practitioner of it with his hand is not found in our time, is: that the art of medicine is long, and its author must exercise beforehand in the science of anatomy, which Galen described, until he knows the functions of the members, and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and tendons, and their number, and their outgoing, and the veins' pulses, and quietness, and the places of their exits.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of that, Hippocrates said that a name with a name is much, and with work is little, and especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already spoken of that at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since he who is not knowledgeable about what we have said concerning anatomy, will not be cautious, and will already fall into error, by which men are harmed: as I have seen many of them, who boast about this science, and speak of it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	What happened was that I saw a physician make an incision into a scrofulous aposteme on a woman's neck and he cut some arteries in the neck, from which the woman's blood flowed until she fell dead at his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another physician who presumed he would extract a stone from a man which had grown inside him over time, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	He therefore approached him, and extracted it with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	For the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I had already been called to extract it, and I saw from the size of the stone and the weakness of the man that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another physician who was receiving a stipend from a certain Duke of our land because of medicine: and it happened to a black eunuch who was with him that he got a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the physician acted with his ignorance, and pressed the fracture above the wound with poultices, and applied a tight bandage, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he treated him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he left him for some days and ordered him not to undo the bandage: and it stayed like that until his leg became apostematic and his foot, and it came to destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was therefore called to him: and I hastened to undo the bandage: and calmness followed, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	But indeed the corruption had already been established in the limb: and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Then the corruption ceased to spread through the limb until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another physician who perforated a cancerous aposteme, and it became an ulcer after some days, until the evil of it became great with its owner.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	What is, that when it is pure cancer from melancholic humor, then it is not suitable to be pierced with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can tolerate it, so that all of it can be cut away.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And on account of that, O sons, it is necessary for you to know that the operation with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, an operation to which health is associated, and an operation in which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already excited in every place of this book, in which comes the operation, in which there is terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	For it is necessary for you to beware of that, and dismiss it: so that the stupid ones do not find a way to speak and to disown.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Receive therefore the measure with solicitude and protection, and your infirm ones with facility and firmness, and use the better way leading by the grace of God to salvation and praiseworthy succession: and dismiss dreadful anxieties of difficult healing: and lift your souls from that which makes you fear, so that hesitation enters into your faith and your commodity.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For it is more remaining to your glory, and sublime in this world, and afterwards to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has already said in certain of his warnings.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not call the evil sickness medicine: nor name the bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	Now, however, I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	The first Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Of the cauterization with fire, and sharp medicine cauterization, chapter and ordained from head to feet, and forms of instruments, and ironments of cauterization: and all that which is necessary in the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	The second Chapter.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Of cutting and piercing, bloodletting and puncture, and wounds: and the removal of arrows, and similar things to that: and the entire chapter, ordered in the forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	The third chapter.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Of restoration and dislocation, and the cure of twisting, and similar things to that: a chapter, ordered from head to foot, and in the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory to God alone.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part One.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Of cauterization and branding: and with which complexions it is suitable, and at what time: and if with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Chapter One.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before which thing it is necessary to recall the quality of its cauterizations and brandings: and in what complexions they are exhibited.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse on the quality of cauterization and branding is a profound and subtle science, and a hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And many wise men have spoken on it, and disagreed about it: and for myself it is enough to take a little from their discourses, fearing a prolonged discussion.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that cauterization is suitable for every complexion, which is with material and without material: excepting two complexions, which are a hot complexion without material, and a dry complexion without material.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	But in the hot and dry complexions with material they disagree.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	For some have said that cauterization is suitable for it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	And others have said the opposite, namely that cauterization is not suitable for a disease which is from heat and dryness: since the nature of fire is heat: and it is unsuitable to cure a hot and dry disease with something hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he said, the one who says the opposite of that: that which is treated by cauterization becomes a remedy in every hot and dry ailment that occurs in the bodies of men: for when you compare the body of a man and its humidities to the complexion of fire, you find the body of a man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I indeed say through his speech: that the experiment has already revealed that to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	But it is not fitting that one should come upon that, unless he has already been proven and exercised in the chapter of Cauterization's final exercise, and knows the diversity of the complexions of men, and the disposition of ailments in themselves, and their causes, and accidents, and the space of time of them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	From the remaining complexions, however, there is not above the use fear: and especially in cold and humid ailments.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all physicians have already agreed upon them, and do not disagree with the remedy of Cauterization in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, my sons, that from the secret of cure by Cauterization with fire, and its goodness over Cauterization with burning medicine is: for fire is simple, whose action does not penetrate except to the member which is cauterized: and does not harm another member joined to it, except with a little injury.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of burning medicine penetrates to that which extends from the members: and perhaps makes occur in a member an ailment of difficult healing, and perhaps kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, on account of its subtlety and goodness of its substance, does not do that, unless it overflows.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	Now that has become known to us through experiment, on account of the length of service and study with art, and position upon the truth of things: and because of that I will excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it were not, I would not be allowed to reveal to you in my book a secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies of expulsion, which expels diseases, demonstrated by philosophical speech, which will be keen in your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And you should know, sons, that they themselves disagree on the time in which it is suitable to apply a cauterization, and they put the best time in the spring.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that a cauterization is suitable at any time, because the harm that occurs on account of the time is outweighed by the benefit that is drawn with the cauterization.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if a cauterization is on account of pains from necessary pains, strong, urgent ones, which do not tolerate delay: because what is feared from them is that a greater evil will occur, which is worse than the small harm that occurs on account of the time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let it not fall into your minds, O sons, that which they do not consider, except the common and stupid physicians, namely that the diseases which are healed by a cauterization, do not always return: and they think that this is a consequence, and the thing is not as they think: because a cauterization is not, unless in place of medicine, which alters the complexion, and evacuates the humors which are the causes, for which pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, a cauterization surpasses medicine by the swiftness of its health, and the virtue of its operation, and the vehemence of its dominion: and it is possible that the disease may return at some hour of time according to the complexion of the weak person, and the location of his disease, and its virtue: and what is prepared in his body from the aggregation of superfluities in it: and what pervades into it in acquiring them from foods, and similar things from causes, unless a disease is made, in which a cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	A subtle inflammation in a member with little superfluity of blood and humidity, such as a cauterization of the tooth, because of pain, and similar to it, is possible that the pain does not return in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that happens in few.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	And I speak to the common people again, that cauterization is the last of medicine, is a straight speech: not according to what they themselves intend in it: since they believe that there is no cure which agrees with medicine, nor with another thing after the application of the cauterization.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	The thing is contrary to that, and the intention, that cauterization is the last of medicine, is not, except that when we administer modes of cure in some disease, and those medicines do not agree: then we administer in the end of the thing cauterization, and it agrees: therefore it falls, that cauterization is the last of medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many foolish medical men understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that cauterization with gold is better than cauterization with iron: and they did not say that except because of the equality of gold, and the sublimity of its substance: and they said that it does not produce pus in the place of the cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But it is not true absolutely: since I have already proved that, and found that it does not do that in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterization with it is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	Truly however when you ignite the cauterization fire from gold, it is not declared to you, when it is ignited according to the quantity that you use, because of the rubedo of the gold: and when it approaches the cold, and if you add ignition on top of it, it melts in the fire, and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Wherefore the artisan falls from that in work: and because of that cauterization with iron is made by us more swiftly and nearer to the truth for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I have already arranged this chapter on cauterization, following the chapters, and I have arranged them from head to feet, so that they provide to the inquirer what he wants from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	On the method of cauterizing the head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Head II or Chapter II, Head
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	This cauterization is beneficial for the domination of humidity and cold over the brain: which two are causes of heaviness, and an abundance of flux of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and an abundance of sleep, and pain in the teeth, and pain in the throat: and universally all sickness which occurs due to cold, such as palsy, and heaviness, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar to those diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is that you should precede the weak with a purging medicine to clean the head for three nights, or four, according to what the strength of the weak person requires, and their age, and their habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then instruct them to shave their head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make them sit between your hands in a square shape, so that they have already placed their hands on their chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of the palm of your hand on the root of their nose between their eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger touches, mark that place with an incision.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then prepare the olive cautery for ignition, whose shape is this.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it on the marked location with an incision, and lower it, by which your hand is contracted little by little, and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then lift your hand quickly, and inspect the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that it has already drawn out from the bone a quantity of head alkali, or a quantity of zeherb, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, you will strike your hand with the iron itself or with another from it if it becomes chilled: until the bones which I mentioned to you are visible.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take something from salt, and dissolve it in water, and soak the cotton in it, and put it on the place: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then put on it a cotton soaked in butter, and leave it on the place, until the eschar is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with the ointment Tetrapharmacon, until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	Now they have said, that the more a wound remains open, the more it emits pus: therefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them have said, that the skin should be cauterized to the bone: and that the cauterization should be held, until there is a thickness like that of bone.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then scrape away what has been burned from the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	And others say that it is necessary to perforate with a cauterization iron to the extreme, until it makes an impression on the bone for a mold, so that the bone falls, which is made like a form of a comb: or the instrument that women use to insert a letter of the alphabet: and they extract, what vapors of the head expire from this place, and the wound is left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then treat it, until it becomes consolidated.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	To me, however, these two kinds of cauterization do not seem suitable except in certain men according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And to leave it, is better with me for the health of itself.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head is weakened from the solution of its natural continuity: as we have testified in the other members: and especially when the head is weak and feeble by nature: and a certain kind of cauterization is more salvatory and better with me, and I use it: therefore operate with it for health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	On the method of cauterizing the head for pain throughout the whole head.
Caput III.	Chapter Three.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When there is chronic pain throughout the whole head: and it is prolonged in the sick person, and they are treated with henna, and cohchia, and head purges, and oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has already been cauterized with a single cauterization, which we have described, and none of those things are of benefit to it: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head of the sick person is of strong natural constitution, and it is not weak, and it meets with vehement cold: then cauterize with another cauterization under that a little.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it on the entire horn of its head with a cauterization, so that it does not penetrate too deeply through the skin, and a quantity is discovered from the bone, which we have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize it with a single cauterization on the back of its head, in the place which is called the "uas": and it is a place where the ventose is applied: and elevate your target in this, and you will not discover bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For the sick person meets with vehement and diverse pain from the pain of all the other cauterizations of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will call this Cauterization in its proper place: and it is necessary that there be a cauterization, with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and its occiput more subtly than the cauterization with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	On the method of cauterizing for hemicania, both with medicated cauteries and with iron.
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When there is pain and inflammation in one part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and it is treated with medicines that cleanse the head, and the rest of the treatment which I mentioned in the divisions of diseases is administered, and none of those things are of benefit: then cauterization in this case is according to two methods: either cauterization with medicated cauteries that burn: or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	Cauterization with acute burning medicine is such that you take one tooth of a gear, and strip it, and cut off its extremities on both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then cut the place of pain at the time with a broad scalpel, until a place under the skin is made, in which the dense part is captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Insert it therefore under the skin, until it is hidden: then bind above it with a bandage of decent constriction, and leave it for fifteen hours; then undo it, and extract the tooth, and leave the wound two days, or three: afterwards put on it a plaster submerged in butter, until the place makes pus: then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you want to make it with certain burning medicines, which I wrote about in the twelfth treatise, on Medicines for burning.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	Cauterization of it with iron is according to this method.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	Fire cauterization, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called a Clavulus: because the form of its head is like the form of a nail, in which there is something curved, and in the middle of it is a certain small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then put it on the place, and hold your hand: and you withdraw the iron little by little with speed: and let the quantity that is burned be from the thickness of the skin, as its middle.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, so that the artery which is below is not burned, and there occurs a flow of blood.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the plaster in salt water, and put it on the place, and leave it for three days: then put a plaster with butter: afterwards treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you want, cauterize this half of the skull with the edge of a second cauterizing knife.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And beware of the incision of an artery in this half of the skull, not being old is a special property.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	On the method of cauterizing in the old half of the skull.
Caput V.	Chapter Five.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you treat the half of the skull, with what we have said from the preceding cure, and what we have said in the divisions of ailments, and the treatment is not effective: and you see from the ailment that what we have said about the first cauterization with medicine or with fire does not suffice for it, then it is necessary to make an igneous cauterization, until it becomes white after you apply a sign above the place of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or about that: and put your hand in place of one, and press it until you cut the artery, and penetrate up to the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	Truly it is necessary for you to beware of the continuity of the jaw, which moves during mastication, lest the side or nerve which moves it be burned, whence spasms occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And let this be above caution and beware of the flow of blood from the artery that has been cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in the cutting of it there is fear, and especially for him who is ignorant of what he does, and is not careful, nor experienced: and he undertakes the operation with this from the beginning.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with a reminder of the regulation of the flow of blood that occurs from an artery according to its own method, and in the place proper to this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	What if you see from the ailment that this cauterization is not sufficient for it, and you see the body of the weak one enduring a cauterization in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, treat the wound until it is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, administer the cauterization that we have spoken of in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a cauterizer having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For cauterization is better than this and more beneficial.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	On the method of cauterizing for earache.
Caput VI.	Chapter Six.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When pain occurs in the ear from cold and it is treated with solutions and the rest of the treatment that we mentioned in the division, and the pain is not relieved, then cauterization by fire: and this is what is called a puncture, whose shape is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then puncture it with that after its ignition all around the entire ear, as it is rotated: or around both, if pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And stretch yourself with the cautery from the root of the ear for a little while, after you have marked the places with ink, and let the quantity of the cautery be ten punctures on the entire ear, or about that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then treat the places until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	On the method of cauterizing for Colic.
Caput VII.	Chapter Seven.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Colic that is treated with cauterization is not except for the types which occur from phlegm, according to what we said in the divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And it requires cauterization of the type that occurs from dryness and spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this type of colic with hiera and purgings and gargling and your treatment does not work, then it is necessary to cauterize the weak area with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and a second a little below the temple, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And put your cauterization on the opposite side from the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur except in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize it with the cauterium directly on the extremity of the ear above, under the horn of the head a little, and another on the temple: whose length is according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And put your hand with a cautery until the quantity of the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of a Cautery, and it is a type of knife, whose form has been described above: nevertheless it is not more refined than that little, as you see: and it should be a knife with a bit of excessive thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then treat the place, with what has preceded, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	On the method of cauterizing in old Apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When the Apoplexy has become old, and you treat it with what we have said, and your medication is not effective, and the weak person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every horn of his head, and a cauterization in the middle of the head, as we have said, and a cauterization on the back of the head, according to what has preceded: and the method of the cauterization should be according to what has preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	And also it is cauterized with a Cautery over the bone of the stomach: and this is the most extreme method.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then let it be treated with what has preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	On the method of cauterizing for Oblivion.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that at first the weak person should be given a drink of great hysteria, and purging pills to cleanse the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the entire head of the weak person, and put on its back an emplaster of snail as described in the treatment of emplasters: and apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This indeed is the method of Cautery: and do that according to the same order which I mentioned there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If therefore he is healed by it, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make for him three cauteries on the back of his head, which should extend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and put between each cauterization the thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then treat the cauterization, together with what has preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	If however you use an application, and he is weak and unable to tolerate it: then apply a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	What if you use an application: then cauterize it on top of the two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then treat it, until it is healed: and let the cauterization be according to the form that has been described beforehand.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	On the method of cauterizing for paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the cleansing of the head with care, and with what we have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then shave the head of the weak person: afterwards cauterize it with a cauterization in the middle of the head, and with a cauterization on top of every horn of the head, and with a cauterization on its back, and with three on the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however you are afflicted with a disease of softening of the body in many places, and he is weak and unable to tolerate it, and the disease is strong: then cauterize him with four cauterizations on the vertebrae of the back, and the last one with a cauterization, until much of its skin is burned, and lift your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then treat it, until it is healed: and thus the cauterization of an olive.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	On the method of cauterizing for epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic is not cauterized, unless it is he whose epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary therefore that you cleanse his brain first with care, and with the rest of the treatment which we have said in the division: when he is greatly weak, or is unable to tolerate the acceptance of medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If however he is a boy, who does not tolerate medicines, then administer a gargle, and cleansing mastications for the brain, before that for many days with improvement of foods.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then shave the head of it, afterwards cauterize it with one cauterization in the middle of the head, according to what has preceded in manner: and cauterize another on the occiput and over every horn of its head with a cauterization.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	What if it is weak and strong and has been tolerating, then cauterize it with the cauterizations that I mentioned in one having paralysis and a softening of the body over the spondiles of the neck and the spondiles of the back: and let the Cauterium be olive oil according to the method which has preceded.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If however it is a weak child, then put a subtle cauterization, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	On the method of cauterizing for Melancholy.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the causes of melancholy are corrupted humours and gross phlegm, then cauterize it with the Cauterizations that we mentioned in one having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is a superfluity inclined to melancholy, and it is a body of an infirm person humidified, then give to it in a drink what will cleanse its brain, according to that which has preceded in the division: afterwards shave the head of the infirm person, and make then a little roll made from linen, as a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then put it in the middle of the head: and let the infirm person sitting squarely be held from every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present an ointment or plaster.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And it is worthy made from old butter of ewe's milk.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And warm it over a fire with a tempered measure of heating, which the finger can tolerate, when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then apply it on the middle of its head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do that to the infirm person every week once, with the rest of its good regimen, until it is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you use it, cauterize it by making many small points, in addition to which you should apply the cautery with a gentle hand while smelling it.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This type of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put on it a cushion soaked in butter, or hen's fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	On the method of cauterizing with water descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the beginning of the water in the eye is declared to you by signs, which I mentioned in the division, then begin and drink the weak one, with that which cleanses its head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And guard it from all moistures, and make it sit in a bath, in fasting for some days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command it to shave its head, and cauterize it in the middle of its head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it above the two temples with two cauteries, if there is a simultaneous descent of water in both eyes; or on one side, if there is a descent of water in one eye: and cut with the cautery all the veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in width of the temples: and cauterize to stop the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	What if you see anything of it, then cut it off immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them, and caution from the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when it is cauterized on the neck, under the two bones, with two cauteries which are produced to the utmost.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	On the method of cauterizing old tears.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are old and frequent: and they are above the veins, and arteries which are on the manifest exterior head, it is verified that this is from cold, phlegmatic superfluities: then cauterize with the same cautery that I mentioned in the descent of water, a cautery in the middle of the head, and two cauteries above the two temples, and two cauteries on the neck under the two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if you notice an increase, then cauterize it on every side with a cautious eye, above the eyebrow with a small cauterizer.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	On the method of cauterizing in the nasal polyp.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat it with what we said in the division and the treatment is not effective then prepare and give a drink of weak cohosh for three nights afterwards shave his head and cauterize it with a moderate cautery iron with an olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with a cautery of the neck, with two cauteries, above the two eyebrows under the hair a little.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of the cautery of the neck.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	On the method of cauterizing for softening of the Eyelid.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye becomes softened from illness or moisture then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows a little with two cauteries on every side and they will be stretched for two times and let the length of every cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow and do not move your hand with the cautery unless according to the quantity that is burned the third of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of the lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	On the method of cauterizing the eyelid when inverted eyelashes prick the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery for this is according to two methods: either a cautery with fire or a cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	For the cautery with fire, instruct the weak one beforehand that he release his eyelashes if he is of those who clean them until they stretch and become even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they prick it at its base: then bind its eyes with a thread, so that they do not move, until they heal.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When therefore the healing and equalizing occur, then put the head of the weak one in your bosom: afterwards apply a mark above the eyelid of its eyes with encaustic, a mark which is according to the figure of the myrtle leaf: and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then put a piece of cloth soaked in egg white on the eye: or in a mucilage of psyllium above the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply cautery with a branding iron, whose shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize over the figure that you marked little by little on many places, until the surface of the skin is burned, which is like the shape of the myrtle leaf, appearing entirely as its own.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the health of your work is: that if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracted, and the hair lifted up at the puncture of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Lift your hand then: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then put on it a piece of cloth with butter, until the scab is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment, until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If some of the hair returns after an hour, and the eyelid becomes soft: then apply cautery again on that place, as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however the hair is on the underside: then cauterize it, until it lifts up to its natural place: and equals out so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	On the method of cauterizing with medicine for burning in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is that you instruct the weak one to let the hairs go, until they grow out and equalize.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from a piece of cloth the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from known soap, and from unabsorbed lime one ounce or about that; then rub them together with good friction, and make it with haste, so that it does not get cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then spread from it over the cloth which you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and put it on the eyelid of one eye, or two.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And put under the eye a piece of cloth imbued with egg white: and let the head of the sick person be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And put your index finger on the medicine, and press it for a little while.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you move it as often as the sick person feels the biting of the medicine: for its biting penetrates like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While therefore it perseveres that which it has found, the biting, then let go of the medicine, and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When therefore the biting subsides, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if you see the eyelid lifted, as it is lifted with contraction from fire, or with incision, it is good: and if not, then apply again upon it of the medicine on the place, where the medicine does not impress, and does not denigrate, until your operation is equal, and the eye is contracted.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then put over it a cloth with butter, until the burned skin is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the ointment called diaphenicum, or another, until it is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you during the operation, to guard with utmost care, lest something from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	What if the eyelid becomes soft after some days, and something from the hair pushes into the eye, then apply again the medicine on that place which becomes soft from the eyelid itself, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that the eyes of men differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore your consideration should be this: and the way of rectitude will not be hidden from him who has a zeal for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	On the method of cauterizing in a tear duct fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you treat a fistula, with what we have said in the divisions of diseases, and your treatment is not effective: then, it is necessary that you cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Order the weak person to place his head on your lap, and let your assistant hold his head between their hands in such a way that it is not moved or agitated with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put a cotton swab under the conjunctiva of the eye, or in the mucus of the eyelid above his eye: then apply the cauterizing iron, whose shape is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be hollow, in the shape of a quill pen from one end, with which the cauterization is made: and if you want it to penetrate up to the other end, and if you want it raised thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However this hollow one is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and extract the sanies from it, and clean it: and if it is not open, then open it, and extract its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put on it the cauterizing iron, which is made very hot.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold your hand for a little while on the cauterizing iron near the eye, towards the nose, so that your hand is not burned, or the weak person is disturbed: and you put the cauterizing iron in the fat of the eye, and consume it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If I cauterize at the beginning up to the mouth, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cauterization once or twice, if you judge that necessary: and diminish it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then put a plaster with butter, and treat it with an excoriating ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	What if forty days pass and it is not healed: then put on it a sharp corroding medicine, until the mouth is laid bare: and scrape it according to what is described in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another method of cauterizing a fistula, which some of the first ones have described.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Direct it to the place of the fistula, and probe it: then put into the same fissure a thin rod, that is, a subtle little tube, whose form is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour into it a quantity of lead melted from a drachm, and hold your hand with the cane in good retention, and do not move the weak one at all, so that the melted lead does not run or penetrate to its eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary that you put on the weak eye a plaster under white of egg, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	For lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	What if the fistula is healed, with what we have said about cauterization, and cure, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to administer the opening of the nose, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what comes to its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cauterizing in the fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Fissures often occur in the lip, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you treat these fissures with what we have said in the division of diseases and the treatment does not work, then apply a small cautery to the knife, according to this method.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let it be shaped according to the fineness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the ignited thing quickly into the fissures until the cautery penetrates to the depth of the fissures.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with a plaster, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the method of cauterizing in a fistula of the mouth.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When an apostema occurs at the root of the gum, or in the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and ruptures: afterwards it becomes chronic and the pus flows out and a fistula forms: then you treat it and if the treatment does not work, then it is necessary to apply a cautery according to the quantity that the fistula can hold.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the ignited thing into the opening of the fistula and hold your hand, until the ignited iron penetrates to its depth and bottom: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then treat it afterwards with what we have said concerning treatment, until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore the sanies is cut off and healed, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to probe the place and remove the corrupted bone according to what is found in its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	On the method of cauterizing the gums and softened teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is softened because of humidity and the teeth are loose and you treat it with medicines and it does not work: then put the head of the weak one in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then apply a cautery, of which the form will be shown after this, so that you put a tube over the tooth: and insert into it the ignited cautery quickly: and hold your hand for a little while, until the weak one feels the heat of the fire has already penetrated to the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift up your hand; then repeat the cauterization several times, according to what you need.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the weak bone fill itself with salt water, and hold it for one hour: and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For a dense movement is strengthened, and the gum softened is tightened, and the corrupted humidity is dried.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	On the method of cauterizing in toothache.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the toothache is due to cold, or there is cold or worm in it, and treatment with medicines does not help: then cauterization in it is according to two methods: either cauterization with butter, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	The cauterization of it with butter is, that you take the butter of a cow, and boil it in an iron spoon, or in a metal vessel.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take the scab, and apply it to the extremity of the aching tooth.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then submerge it in the boiling butter: and apply it quickly to the aching tooth, and hold it until it cools: then repeat it several times, until the power of the fire penetrates to the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, submerge a thread, or a scab in cold butter, and apply it to the aching tooth: and put on top of it a heated iron, until the fire penetrates to the depth of the hollow of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The cauterization of it with fire is, that you direct a bronze or iron tube.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be in its body something of thickness, so that the sharpness of the fire does not penetrate to the weak tooth.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then cauterize with fire, of which the form appears: and apply it to that tooth: and hold your hand, until the cauterization cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do that several times, for the pain will be relieved, either on that same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it is fitting with the application of that cauterization, that the weak part of his mouth be filled with good butter, and that he hold it for one hour; then he spits it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	And this is the form of the Cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with whatever extremity you use second to that which is possible: and this is the form of the Cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	On the method of cauterizing in the tracts.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the Strophulae are from phlegm and from cold humidities, and they do not obey digestion through medicines, and you use digestion of them quickly: then a cauterization with fire is concave, whose form is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that the smoke can go out at the cauterization from one extremity to the other: and put the ignited thing on the aposteme once, and a second time, if you apply it there, until it reaches the depth of the aposteme.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	Which if the aposteme is small: then put the cauterization according to the quantity of the aposteme.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then leave it for three days, and put on it a plaster under butter, until that which the fire burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then treat it with a dentifrice ointment, until the form of the cannula is healed.
