Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of extracting certain arrows: so that you put that rule and meaning on that which I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with narration: nor does the book comprehend it, and the skillful artisan compares a little with much: and with what is present, with that which is absent: and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument according to the descent of extraneous things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed, except according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by traction from the place into which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite part of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, is an arrow proceeding into a fleshy place: and is drawn, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	For if it does not obey to exit at the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you leave it for some days, until the flesh which is around it putrefies: and its attraction will be alleviated, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it is fixed in a bone, and does not obey you to exit, then leave it also for some days: and move it with attraction and motion every day, until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	For if it does not obey you to exit after days, then it is necessary that you perforate around the arrow in the bone on every side with a subtle drill, until the arrows are freed.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already proceeded into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of those accidents which I mentioned appear from below: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and leave it, until its inflammation subsides after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	If an arrow penetrates to the spleen, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless it is in the body to the extent of a bone, and does not penetrate up to the spleen: and he remains weak for some days, and none of those accidents happen to him: then devices are used for attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If the arrow is fixed deeply, and does not yield to attraction: then administer a drill in the vicinity of the arrow, as I have told you: then treat the area until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If the arrow is already hidden in a location of the body, and is concealed and hidden from sensation: then investigate it with probing.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then attract it with certain instruments that are suited to its attraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot reach it, on account of the constriction of the wound, and on account of the length of the arrow in the depth: and there is not a bone, nor a nerve, nor a vein: then probe above it, until the wound is enlarged, and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	What if there are to him nerves that hold it, then free the flesh fixed in them on all sides, with every device that you can, and devices, if it cannot overcome the swelling of the flesh in the fracture of the ears, and their distortion, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then use distortion of your hand, with forceps on all sides, until you make it come out: and proceed with ultimate subtlety, so that the arrow is not broken, and its attraction and extraction become difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	What if you cannot overcome it in one hour, then leave it for some days, until what are around it putrefy.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for the tunic will be loosened, if indeed a contrary condition makes for you an efflux of blood, then administer what we said concerning treatment in its own chapter: and preserve your strength from the incision of a vein, or nerve, or cord.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the arrow's extraction in every way that is possible for you, and let it be with facility, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, as I have narrated to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is fitting, that you do when you draw out the arrow, that the weak part be according to the figure, according to which it was in the case of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is a greater assistance.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If however it is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which comes out from the opposite part of another, or already proceeds from it something to the exterior: or makes a gibbosity of the extremity of the arrow by sensation from the upper part of the adjacent skin, and you see it prominent: make an incision over it, and let the incision be according to the quantity that the forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out: for it becomes easy to come out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If indeed it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until the arrow impresses itself in the bone, and enlarges itself: then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for some days: then repeat it, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	What if the wood of the arrow is in it, then push it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If however the wood has fallen, and you want to administer a push: then introduce to it a hollow instrument, so that its hollow enters into the tail of the arrow: then push it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If however the arrow head is barbed then push it out with an instrument entering into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is indeed pulled out through that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	What if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary, that the barbed flesh, in which is the venom, be cut out: if it is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with what is suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	What if the arrow falls in the breast, or in the stomach, or in the bladder, or in the side: and is near to that which you touch with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware of cutting the vein, or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then sew the wound, if you see it, and treat it, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let there be similar extremities like a bird's beak, which are made like iron: when they grasp above the arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many types are made from them, large and small and medium, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow, and its thinness, and the width of the wound, and its constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The form of a pusher for barbed things.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of a pusher for pointed things.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the extremity of the rod, like a radius, so that its entrance is pulled out from the barbed arrow, and it is pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this pusher for the barbed thing is barbed like a bird's feather, so that the entrance of the arrow is pulled out into it and its thrust.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Of the venesection of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 98.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins for bloodletting, whose cutting custom has run in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	From which there are in the head sixteen: two pulsating Veins, which are behind the ears, called two Herbae; and two Arteries, which are on both temples apparent; and two Veins which are in both tear ducts of the eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a Vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegi, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The Veins however which are bled in the arms, are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and it is from the left side: and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Median vein, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilica and a branch of the Cephalica: and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the cord of the arm, and it is placed above the elbow: and it is that in which bloodletting is performed, and it is that which appears above the thumb with a clear manifestation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is the vein which is between the ring finger and the little finger: and there are two branches of it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the knee joint on the left side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its location is near the heel on the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the third is the Vena Nesse: and its location is near the heel on the outer side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three similar veins.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On the bloodletting of two veins behind the Ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bloodletting of the two veins which are behind the Ears is a remedy for ancient catarrhs and hemicrania and sahafati and old bad head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting it is according to what I will narrate.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is that the head of the weak person should be rubbed: and his occiput should be rubbed in the place of the two veins with a rough cloth and good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the weak person should bind his neck with a cord, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are behind the Ears in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Seek them therefore with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there mark with a cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the lancet for bloodletting, and it is that which is called the Incisor.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it under the vein in the skin, until the bloodletter reaches the opening.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut the vein with the skin with an incising cut.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or about that, and make come out from the blood as much as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with dressings, and leave it, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now the cutting of them has been dealt with at the beginning of the book, and also their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On the bloodletting of two Arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two arterial veins that are in the two temples for bloodletting, the remedy is for old migraine: and foul sore, and constant eye disease: and the running of overflowing acrid humors to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting them is according to what I relate to you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak one will press his neck strongly, until two veins appear with a clear visible appearance: and the pulse of them will be shown under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark with cauterization.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then raise the skin above the vein with your index finger, and insert the bloodletting needle underneath, and raise the vein to the upper parts.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you have done with the two other veins: and make the blood flow according to the quantity of your necessity.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then release the constriction of the weak one, and put your finger on the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterwards put a plaster and poultices on it, and bind it strongly above with a tight bandage: and leave it, until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now the recollection of them has passed, and their cutting, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	Of the bloodletting of the vein of the forehead after the bloodletting of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The remedy of the bloodletting of the vein of the forehead is after the bloodletting of the head, for old facial pains: and for migraine, and redness: and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of its bloodletting is, according to what I relate to you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The weak one constricts his neck with a band, until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument that is called a Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	Whose shape is this.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place a prominent needle which is on the head of the vein, and strike above it with the pectoral or with another tool in its manner, and let blood flow according to the quantity that you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then loosen the weak perforation, and constrict it, until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad phlebotome.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	But truly it is not suitable, that the phlebotome should be of sharp extremity, as are the rest of the phlebotomes, but rather of broad extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And let the phlebotome be according to the crossing, because the bone is nearby, and perhaps the phlebotome will break when it is subtle.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	Of the venesection of the veins in the two lachrymals.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The treatment of the two veins which are in the two lachrymals of the two eyes, is for an eye affected by itch and redness, and dirt in the eye, and facial pains.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of the venesection of them is, that the weak neck constricts itself with a thread.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then perform venesection on them, and you should stand above its head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let the venesection be according to the crossing for a small length, with a small phlebotome, slightly broad, for there is no flesh in the location.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	For if the phlebotome is of subtle extremity, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make the blood flow as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And put a plaster on them, and constrict them for one night, and then loosen them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Of the venesection of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The venesection of the veins of the nose is beneficial for acute fever and violent sweating, and facial pains, such as half-headache and redness which occurs on the face, especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of his bloodletting is that it constricts the weak part of the neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a subtle, long bloodletting instrument: and insert it into the middle of the lip, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Since a vein does not appear to sensation there, and because blood begins to flow at once.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you withdraw your hand with the bloodletting instrument for a short time: and make the blood flow according to your necessity.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it with one bandage at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For it is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Of the bloodletting of the veins according to Guidetti.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The instrument of Guidetti's bloodletting is for constriction of asthma, and for the interception of leprosy, and melancholic diseases, and for bad impetigo and ulcers, and corroding, that is, herpes and itching.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of their bloodletting is that it constricts the weak under both with a bandage on the neck: and let the practitioner stand over the head of the weak person, and the weak person be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then let the bloodletting instrument pierce the vein to the length of the broad bloodletting for a short time.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then extract from the blood a moderate quantity, or according to that which you see is necessary for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards loosen the bandage, and constrict the two veins in the middle tightly: so that the weak person is not suffocated.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And leave it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound will be healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Of the bloodletting of the veins according to Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The instrument of Algeberich's bloodletting of the veins is because it helps against bad breath in the mouth, and corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers: and cracks of the lips, and bad ulcers, also those which are in the nose, and in its surroundings.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	The quality of bloodletting of the veins is that you should make the weak sit before you and stretch their neck with a towel.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then uncover the lip of it, and look at the two veins: one of which is to the right of the lip, and the second to the left of it: and the demonstration of both is through the blackness of the gums.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that vein is because around the edges of them there are small, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut therefore both with an incision of the falling.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If however there is doubt about you, and you do not know which of them it is: then proceed to the cutting of the larger one, and its more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do likewise concerning the two veins which are in the upper lip: and mostly custom runs with it: and cut the two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	Of bloodletting of the vein under the tongue after the bloodletting of the head.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The aid of the two veins which are under the tongue for bloodletting is, that the bloodletting of the head is for the afflictions which are in the throat, and the sickness of the uvula, and the sicknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bloodletting them is that the weak should sit between your hands before you in the sun: and raise their tongue, and look under the tongue on one side a vein, and on the other side a vein: and the color of both declines to blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Bloodlet therefore both: and beware, lest you wound your hand in bloodletting them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under them are arteries, and perhaps it happens that there is a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins which are bloodlet in the elbow, are where bloodletting custom runs in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And bloodletting of the ears is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pricking with a broad myrtle-shaped lancet, or with an olive-shaped one for subtlety, or by cutting with a knife-shaped lancet, and it is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is what suits for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are broad and subtle types according to the width of the veins and their tightness The form of the myrtle-shaped lancet is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it suits for opening hollow veins, full ones, protruding ones, visible ones, thick ones, and those which contain coarse, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of lesser breadth, and of more subtle extremity.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it suits for bloodletting of subtle veins, which contain subtle yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On the bloodletting of royalty.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The royal vein, which is one of these three veins for bloodletting, is a privilege.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	For it extracts blood from illnesses which are under the throat and neck, following the chest and stomach: and it suits the bloodletter to bloodlet with it, so that he may beware, and be above fear of it, for beneath it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs, and adds to the prick of the lancet, he will cut that artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Wherefore it is necessary that the bloodletter does not bloodlet with the lancet, but rather cuts with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	Which if it does not appear with a clear royal appearance, then it is necessary that you displace it, and change to another, or seek some branch of it: or in place of the bloodletting, use a ligature on the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It itself is obvious, and cut it with a lancet, Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	But if you perform phlebotomy on the same, then it is necessary before the tightening of the arm, so that you touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark on the place with a cauterizing agent, afterwards the arm, and cut the vein with a concave section using a lancet, Alnesil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And beware that the blow does not fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, as you tie the ligature, an inflation in the place that you marked with a cauterizing agent, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: avoid it therefore.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	For if you see blood in phlebotomy jumping, like the urine of a child, and it is subtle, red blood: then know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then press closely, and put your finger on it over a long space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If the blood is then cut off (for it is often cut off), then tie the arm, and let it be: and let the weak one beware of its motion: and let him be above its fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And do not move it for some days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if the blood does not stop, and overcomes you: and your medicine is not present at the moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For the extremities of it contract, and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Take the bark of a plant, and bind it: take one half, and tie it over the place of the vein with a proper tightening, with a ligature and poultices until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then the cure itself with that which preceded it, a remembrance of the place of powders for cutting off the flow of blood: and the cutting off of its blood is not difficult in many dispositions, on account of the smallness of the place of the wound, and the possibility of binding from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the bloodletting of the dark vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The bloodletting of the dark vein is a remedy, which draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because it is composed of the branch of the Royal and the branch of the Head, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is suitable for the bloodletter to be cautious with it, that he should be above fear from its bloodletting, for beneath it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the puncture of the bloodletting and finds the nerve, there occurs in it numbness, and its healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it will not be completely healed.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve often appears to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If however it is hidden in some men, and is subtle, and does not show itself: then it is necessary that you place your bloodletting where you will bloodlet with a cut with Alnesil, and divert the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	Which if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein in its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	Of the vein of the head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The bloodletting of the vein of the head is a remedy, because it attracts blood from the head and applies to diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein especially, if you wish, that you bloodlet it by pricking with an olive bloodletter, or with a myrtle bloodletter: because it is the savior of all veins, because there is not beneath it an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	The vein that suits you for bloodletting is the one where you find the head of the elbow, and you look for a thinner spot: and it does not harm if it is not found with the first puncture, so that it is repeated over it several times with the bloodletting instrument.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	However a vein perhaps forms an abscess in some men when it is not bloodletted at the first puncture, but that abscess does not harm it in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of Bloodletting, and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of the bloodletting however, and its accidents that arise from it, are things in which you should consider correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First therefore it is that which you ought to know, that bloodletting is not administered except in the conservation of health and its preservation and caution against the approach of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that bloodletting is done on one of the three veins that are in the elbow, namely the Cephalic, and the Fusca, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that bloodletting is done at the beginning of spring on an empty stomach, and in summer, and autumn, and winter after digestion, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And bloodletting is done on the first day, or on the third, after three hours have passed from the day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Bloodletting which is administered in diseases does not have a determined hour, but when convenience and necessity provoke it, at night or day, and every hour, and every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not suitable for children to be bloodletted until fourteen years are upon them.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be bloodletted, except from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should old men be bloodletted, who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When someone wants to undergo bloodletting for any condition, it is necessary that they cleanse their intestines before bloodletting with a mild enema, if there is a lot of retained feces in them, so that the veins do not attract putrid and harmful superfluities from the intestines during bloodletting to the principal members.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should bloodletting be performed on a patient who is vomiting, that is, with nausea, nor one who is drunk or vomiting from intoxication, until that is removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor one who is weak with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And bloodletting should be avoided again after a colic passion, and vomiting, and flux of the belly, and frequent intercourse, and labor, and exercise, and wakefulness, and fasting, and anything that dissolves virtue from the bodily or animal substance.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors beforehand, if the blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medicines, if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let him take a bath, if nothing prevents it, or let him be exercised with some exercise, so that the blood is made subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place bloodletting on his chest, around the third hour of the day, as we have said: and take care, that his chest is evacuated that day from all bad animal accidents, such as anxiety, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and punishment, and excessive evacuations, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him have present things with which usage has created a habit in men from aromatics, and perfumes, and incense and similar things to the quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the one performing bloodletting sit on a cushion, which is higher than the cushion of the one undergoing bloodletting: afterwards let him draw out his arm, and rub it with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he should tie the ligature with a bandage, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And the tightening should be moderate, because when the tightening is uneven, or excessive, it prevents the flow of blood; and similarly in leniency, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the tightening it is necessary that the one performing the bloodletting should rub his hands together until the veins become swollen and declare themselves to the sensation.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the one performing the bloodletting should wipe the vein with a little old oil, properly.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he should place his index finger of the left hand on the vein under the spot where he wants to perform the bloodletting, so that the vein does not flee and the puncture is made.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For the vein is like a fleeing string when it comes to bloodletting: and of them there are those which are full of wind: and when you place the lancet on it, it contracts under the lancet, and the one performing the bloodletting is deceived, and the vein does not open: and if it does open, it is constricted: therefore it is necessary that the one performing the bloodletting should be steady, and be careful in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he should apply the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then the vein is opened from one side, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then he should try the other side under that same spot a little, or above it with speed, if the spot is not damaged.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	What if the spot becomes inflamed, or becomes weak, then let it be for a day, or two days: and do not tie the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps the warm poultice will attract the inflammation.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And let him not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he should repeat the bloodletting if it is loved.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	What if the opening is small, or the blood flows subtly and it happens that the amount does not come out of the blood as the force: then insert the lancet in the same opening according to the straightness, and add a little in the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do that with speed, before the part becomes inflamed, for an inflamed part is in many men near a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see it already inflamed, then do not go over it at all, for it does not excuse anything with regard to you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put on it something from the dregs of oil: since it alleviates the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than the oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the dregs of oil in all your bloodletting, which you perform on veins to prohibit the flow of blood: and they call it tyrical alfarach, and sagzenea, when it is put from one of them on the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For the blood is refined and resolved, when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	What if there happens a great inflammation in the place of bloodletting, for it often happens, especially to him who is not accustomed to bloodletting except by chance, or is the opening of the vein small, then hasten and put on the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed a little: and bind it for one hour: since it loosens.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do that after the blood has come out from the same vein, when its flow is complete, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	What if there remains in the place after days something blackish or greenish, it does not harm: and if you want, put on it something of aloes, or a solution of myrrh: or something from the juice of mint, that is, calament or something similar.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times there occur apostems and enlargements with phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore put your hand on it, then if you find softness with compression of it, then that enlargement is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Beware therefore, that you put on it something of what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood flows from the arterial vessel.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for it with that in which there is astringency, so that the place is hardened.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you extract from every man blood according to the quantity of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the color conquering over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it exit, until it becomes red: and similarly if you see it thick: then let it exit, until it becomes subtle: and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for one who is full, strong, and needs extraction of blood twice, that the phlebotomy of the vein be amplified, and the phlebotomist be warned: and in him who is weak, let it be the opposite of that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he extract it in the veins, and that the opening be narrow: and better that which is administered in phlebotomy of the vein, is that it be a cross-section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the cutting of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and safer than phlebotomy by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is accustomed to faint at phlebotomy of the syncopis, it is necessary that he eat before phlebotomy moderate bread infused in water of pomegranate or secaniabin, if it is warmed: and extract from him blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is of a cold complexion, then let it receive before phlebotomy bread soaked in juice of myrrh or in syrup of honey aromatized with spices, or in syrup aromatized with fragrant odors.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	What if it happens to faint at phlebotomy, and the cause of this is the exit of much blood: then it should take in drink water of flesh, and subtle fragrant syrup: and make use of aromatics with gum, and let its chest be bound with it: and make use of the remainder which we said in the division on the chapter of fainting from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to evacuate his arm and release his blood a second time: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is because of much evacuation, and the virtue of which is weak, that he release blood little by little according to the quantity of virtue in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever indeed wishes to evacuate his arm and release his blood a second time, and his body is strong: then let him do that after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body from the opposite part to which it inclines: it is necessary that he be evacuated on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and it causes fever to happen: it is necessary that blood go out from it at once, and a large quantity be extracted from it: and the opening be enlarged until fainting happens: after you have observed all the conditions of phlebotomy: and that you put your hand on his pulse during the flow of blood, so that death does not happen in place of fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	For it often happens, when the phlebotomy practitioner is ignorant, and negligence occurs.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not necessary when the vein has been opened to release the arm and release blood a second time, since the opening of the vein has already been closed, and the exit of blood becomes difficult, so that it is pressed upon with force, and the curved [needle] is extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a malignant ulcer, or it diminishes itself, until it is blooded a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Remove it with the sharpness of bloodletting that which has coagulated from blood in the opening of the vein, and put upon it something of salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put upon it something from theriac of Alfaroch, or Sagzenea, and apply to it a gentle compression, until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If then the vein is an apostema, leave it, and do not touch it, until the apostema subsides.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	What if necessity demands to release the blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either bloodlet it above that place, or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm are bloodlet at the place of the Fuscus and the Basilicus, when they are not found, and are hidden, because it is composed from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of its bloodletting is, that the weak hand is inserted into hot water, until it becomes red and the vein appears manifestly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then let it be bound above it with a ligature of moderate constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then bloodlet across a little at a time, not in width, nor in length: and let the opening be wide, and your bloodletting be that which you bloodlet upon the joint of the hand for a short while.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	What if the exit of blood is forbidden, then put the hand again in hot water, and let the blood flow into the water, until you obtain your necessity.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If however you are in the days of summer, then you are excused from putting the hand again in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And the flow of blood into hot water is used a lot in the time of winter.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And the bloodletting of this vein is a savior to all veins, because there is not under it a pulsating vein, nor a nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Venesection of the right hand is conducive to ailments of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of its venesection is that you bind the veins of the hand with a ligature, or with your hand, after you have inserted it in warm water until the vein becomes inflamed and is demonstrated to sensation strongly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then venesect the vein by making a cross incision.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it completely, it will not harm it in anything.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And beware, lest you venesect your own hand.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then put the hand in warm water, and let the blood flow into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat it in warm water, the blood congeals in the opening of the vein, and is prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have extracted the amount of blood necessary, then put oil and salt on the vein: so that it does not close quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly it is necessary to do with every constricted branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The remedy of venesection on the left hand is: because it is conducive to ailments of the spleen: and do similarly in its venesection as you did in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The remedy of venesection of the saphena vein is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as ailments of the uterus, and retention of menses, and weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and thighs, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of its venesection is that the weak person inserts their foot into warm water: and makes friction on it until the veins become swollen: and binds above the joint of the foot with a ligature.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the place of the vein is near the heel, visible towards the thumb: and many branches ramify from it on the sole of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Bloodletting is performed on the larger branch of it, or at the heel in its connection, because it is better and more beneficial for health.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	What if bloodletting is performed on the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are under it above the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And put your bloodletting where you perform it from a transverse position, as if you wish to cut it, and let the bloodletter be Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the flow of blood is stopped, then immerse the foot in warm water, and let the blood flow into it, until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	What if the bloodletter misses the vein at first, then repeat the bloodletting towards the upper parts for a little while, for the place is safe, and you will not get harm from it, when you beware of the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel on the wooded side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the indication for bloodletting of it is, for pain of the hip, when it is due to warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of its bloodletting is, that the weak enter the bath and be bound, and let the leg be constricted on the side of the hip up to above the heel four fingers, with a thin long bandage, for it does not appear except because of this.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it appears, then perform bloodletting according to whatever method is possible for you, or according to a crosswise position, and it is better, either that you cut it with an incision, or that you cut it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For its location is safe, and it is hidden in many men to a great extent.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	What if you do not find it, and it does not appear to the senses at all, then perform bloodletting on some branch of it, and it is that which appears on the back of the foot, and opposite the ear, and beware of the nerves, and let the blood flow in quantity as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tightening, and put a piece of leather over the place of bloodletting, and constrict the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For it will heal quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	Of Purging, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter 98.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Clysters are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Purging is done in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With scarification, and the extraction of blood: and the other is purging without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this Purgation which is without scarification, is according to two methods.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the purgings that are administered with scarification and the extraction of blood, are in fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the purging of Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and the purgings of Alhagdahim, and they are two sides of the neck from both parts together: and the purgings of the jaw, and it is under the jaw in the lower mouth: and the purgings of the two shoulders: and the purgings of Alachosos above the end of the tail: and the purgings of the two armpits, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and the purgings of the two thighs: and the purgings of the two hams.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And this Purgation does not extract blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of that, virtue does not come out from them, as is the case with bloodletting.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Nor is it necessary to administer purging, either with fire or without fire, in any of the illnesses that occur from overfilling, until the whole body is emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	What if necessity calls for Purgation from illness, or because of habit, we administer it at every hour, at the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and in the middle of it, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	What is it, that which is from humans who when the blood in them multiplies to the point that it requires extraction through venesection, finds in its head a heaviness and swooning.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And there is from them one who finds fullness and redness in his face, his head, and his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And there is from them one who finds itching in his face and his forehead, and darkness and dimness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And there is from them one who scratches the place of his venesection.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And there is from them one whose sneezing is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And there is from them one who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or it collects on his tongue and he spits up blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is from them one whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there is from them one who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and the slain, and wounds, and things that are similar to those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see any of these things, and it is properly so in the third day of the month: we then order venesection to be done, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The juice of the Venesection of the nut, is: because it brings about heaviness in the head, and that which flows to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But indeed it should be that it is after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this Venesection is in place of the phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not permitted that one who is of a cold complexion, or in whom there is a catarrh, should use it.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings to them great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And because of that it is not fitting that the old use it, and those in whose head there are cold agues.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	He who does it frequently over it, is overcome by forgetfulness.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And because of that, it is necessary to instruct the one performing the surgery, that he should put his hand with the cannula for a short time towards the lower parts, fearing the generation of an obstruction.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosatio or Alkehel is in place of phlebotomy of the spleen and phlebotomy of Basilic, and because of that it treats asthma and constriction of breathing and fissure of the instrument of breathing and coughing and replenishment.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that the cannula of Alkehel be pushed in for a short time, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Ventosatio indeed is a treatment for accidental pains in the head, and diseases of the eyes, and migraines, and perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is in place of phlebotomy of Basilic.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary to instruct the one performing the surgery, that he should not press his hand with the incision: so that he does not cut the artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Ventosatio under the chin treats ulcers in the mouth and corruption of the gums and similar things from diseases which are in the mouth: and it is in place of phlebotomy of the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	Ventosatio of the spatula treats the alchafacham, which is caused by retention and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Ventosatio indeed of the interior parts of the two armpits treats the place of phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilic, and Splenic, and Cephalic: because it itself draws blood from all those tiny little veins which are in the flesh: and those tiny little veins draw from other thicker ones until the drawing reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary to instruct the one performing the surgery, that he should not proceed far in the incision: because the area is bare of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	A vein that is cauterized on the alchausos constricts hemorrhoids and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary to warn the cauterizer that the cautery should be large and made of copper: because the location requires strong suction and subtle cauterizations are likely to break.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Cauteries of the hips diminish with obvious reduction: because they attract blood from the whole body and increase old pains in the kidneys, bladder, and uterus: they provoke menstruation, and cause bothor and ademenul: and they take the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	However, they weaken the body greatly, and cause syncope to occur in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the benefit of cauterizing the alhorcobene is similar to the benefit of cauterizing both hips.
